column9: I have found there is a difference in the medication which comes from different distributers of Pantoprazole (of which there are 3-4 I am told).  I just suffered a severe reaction after getting a refill.  I found my iniitial prescription said Pantoprazole 40mg tab KRE and the new refill said Pantoprazole 40 mg tab DR.  The pills look totally different and apparently the ingredients are not the same much to my misfortune.  Be careful and check you pills when you pick up your new prescription.

column1: Condition in which Stomach Acid is Pushed Into the Esophagus
column2: KC, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I have used pantoprazole 40mg for many years for GERD,  usually the generic for Protonix and I have had no problems and my symptoms have been relieved.  Recently my insurance company, Aetna, changed the generic I was taking to one manufactured by "Dr Reddys".  It smells very foul and tastes worse.  My symptoms are back with a vengence.  I called Aetna to complain but, of course their motto is Profit Before Patient Well Being.  I have now called my doctor to change the prescription and will have to pay for Protonix.  I am going to report Dr Reddys (corporate headquarters in INDIA) to the FDA, not that it will help.  Those of you having problems with pantoprazole drugs should look into the manufacturer, that is probably the issue.

column1: Condition in which Stomach Acid is Pushed Into the Esophagus
column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Protonix worked excellent for first two years until insurance changed me over to Pantoprazole. I've been on Pantoprazole for about three years now and it has lost it's effectiveness. First started noticing decline in effectiveness about three months ago and getting much worse at an increasingly faster rate. Old symptoms have returned: excessive belching, extreme heartburn, intestinal gas. Taking an extra Pantoprazole helps for about one hour then symptoms return. Will try to get back on Protonix if insurance allows. Tried many meds in past but Protonix was flawless! Pantoprazole just isn't a true replacement for Protonix. Insurance companies know this but their bottom line is most important to them! Too bad for us!

He gave me some other pills for upper digestive track issues...  but nothing for the constipation.  It was an awful 12 hours for nothing.  I finally bought Florastor after leaving the hospital, and it worked.  What's wrong with these doctors...  and machines out of calibration.  I have most of the Pantoprazole in the closet.

column9: I was prescribed Protonix in 2003 when I was diagnosed with a Hiatal Hernia. I have never been on any OTC acid reducer or Rx. This med cured me within 6 - 8 weeks. I still occasionally have episodes that require me to use the med for a week or two. Last year BCBS would not authorize me to get the name brand (Protonix) but I was able to get this generic. This med is worthless. I agree with many users here, that this is nothing like Protonix. It was non-effective. Thankfully BCBS will now authorize me to use the name brand, Protonix, now that I have given this generic drug a chance. I have a $35 co-pay for 30 days, and -0- co-pay with this one and I much rather pay for the Protonix. My pharmacist told me that Wyeth does not make the generic, now I understand why it doesn't work the same. Run from this one.

And Pantaprazole even has the nerve to write in their handouts from the drug store that you can take AN ANTACID WITH IT IF YOU NEED TO.
